title: Case Study: Scleroderma with Musculoskeletal Manifestations
clinical_history: A 45-year-old female patient, diagnosed with limited systemic scleroderma (lSSc) 5 years ago, presents with complaints of skin tightness, thickening, and hardening of the skin on her hands, forearms, and face. She reports difficulty moving her fingers, wrists, and elbows due to stiffness and pain. The patient also experiences fatigue, and difficulty performing daily activities such as dressing, grooming, and household chores.
aggrevating_factors: cold temperatures, stress, and prolonged periods of inactivity
picture: A 24-hour picture showing morning stiffness lasting several hours, with gradual improvement throughout the day
easing_factors: warm baths, physical therapy, and gentle exercises
past_history: Raynaud's phenomenon 10 years ago, which resolved spontaneously
medical_history: diagnosed with lSSc 5 years ago, with gradual progression of skin and musculoskeletal symptoms
personal_history: married with two children, works part-time as an administrative assistant, and enjoys gardening and reading in her free time
imaging: X-rays of hands showing joint space narrowing and calcifications, and DEXA scan showing osteopenia
